questions.text: If the systolic BP in a population has a mean of 130 mmHg and a median of 140 mmHg, the distribution is said to be:

choices.text: Either negatively or positively skewed depending upon the standard deviation

questions.solution:
This is a negatively skewed distribution.

In any skewed distribution (i.e., positive or negative), the median will always fall in between the mean and the mode.

For a positively skewed distribution, the mean will always be the highest estimate of central tendency, and the mode will always be the lowest estimate of central tendency (assuming that the distribution has only one mode).

For negatively skewed distributions, the mean will always be the lowest estimate of central tendency, and the mode will be the highest estimate of central tendency.

In this scenario, the median is greater than the mean. As the median lies at a point in between the mean and the mode, this indicates a negatively skewed distribution.

questions.text: Which of the following tests of significance and data group for which it is used, is incorrectly paired?

choices.text: ANOVA - test difference between 3 different groups
Student's t test - test difference between 2 independent groups
Chi square test - test difference between two quantitative variables
Paired t test - test before and after data

questions.solution:
Chi-square test is a nonparametric test that assesses the significance of association between two qualitative variables.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: As an intern in the community medicine department , you are asked to study about the various graphical representation of data. What is the following graph best used for ?

choices.text: Correlating risk factors of a disease
Studying the periodic trends of disease over time

questions.solution:
The graph depicted is a Kaplan-Meier plot, and the graph is used for survival time analysis.

Survival time analysis includes the study of:

  • What is the survival time of patients with a given disease
  • How does this survival time compare between two groups of patients given different treatments for the same disease
  • Among those who survive up to a certain time, at what time or rate can they be expected to die
  • What factors, such as risk factors or treatments, affect the survival time

Despite its name, survival analysis can be used to help answer questions of this kind about any kind of event, not just death—such as how long it takes before a hip replacement fails, how long it takes before a patient has a second heart attack, or how long it takes for coronary stents to become re-stenosed.

Other options:

Option A and C - Scatter diagrams correlate risk factors of a disease and present as a positive correlation, negative correlation, or no correlation. The line of best fit is used to express a relationship in a scatter plot of different data points as a straight line rather than multiple dots. It is an output of regression analysis and can be used as a prediction tool.

Option D - Line diagram is used to study the periodic trends of a disease over time.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: Identify the plots with the maximum interquartile range and the least median respectively.
questions.solution:
The graph shown is a boxplot where Plot 1 has the maximum interquartile range and Plot 2 has the least median.

A boxplot is a method for graphically depicting groups of numerical data through their quartiles. Box plots may also have lines extending vertically from the boxes (whiskers), indicating variability outside the upper and lower quartiles, hence the terms box-and-whisker plot. 

It shows the five-number summary of a set of data as shown below.

In the box plot, a simple box extends from the 25th percentile (lower limit of the box) to the 75th percentile (upper limit of the box) and represents the interquartile range. The interquartile range is maximum in Plot 1 and least in Plot 4. The line through the box indicates the median value (50th percentile). The median is highest in Plot 3 and least in Plot 2.

Interpreting the box plot:

  • When the median is in the middle of the box and the whiskers are about the same on both sides of the box, i.e when each quartile is of the same length, then the distribution is symmetric or normal (as shown in box plot-1)
  • When the median is closer to the bottom of the box, and if the whisker is shorter on the lower end of the box, then the distribution is positively skewed (skewed right, as shown in box plot-2)
  • When the median is closer to the top of the box, and if the whisker is shorter on the upper end of the box, then the distribution is negatively skewed (skewed left, as shown in box plot-3)
  • Small circles or unfilled dots are drawn on the chart to indicate where suspected outliers lie. Filled circles are used for known outliers (as shown in box plot-4)

Related Pearl: Box and Whisker Plot

  • A box and whisker plot is used to show variation in a set of data.
  • They can summarize data from various sources and display it in a single graph.
  • A box and whisker plot is usually based on median, quartiles and percentiles.
  • It is also called a box plot.
  • In the box plot as shown in the image, a simple box is divided into two by the median value. Above and below it are the whiskers. The top and bottom ends of the whiskers are the highest and lowest value of that group. 
  • A box plot can help in identifying outliers and the interquartile range (IQR), as shown in the image below.

questions.text: The results of a meta-analysis of studies comparing a novel drug for diabetes to a reference drug are given below. Which of the following conclusions can be drawn from it?

choices.text: Study E has the lowest sample size.
Studies A and C are statistically significant.
The novel drug is better than the reference drug.
Studies D and E cross the line of no effect.

questions.solution:
The image shown is that of a forest plot. It is used for plotting the results of a meta-analysis. Since the diamond at the bottom, which represents the overall pooled results of all the studies, corresponds to a risk ratio of 2.2, it indicates that the novel drug is better than the reference drug.

In the plot for each study, the size of the rectangle represents the sample size. In this case, study 'E' has the largest sample size (option A). The horizontal line on either side of the rectangle represents the 95% confidence interval for that study.

The solid vertical line that corresponds to the odds ratio of 1 is called the line of no effect. It indicates that there is no significant difference between the reference and the novel drug. Any study line that crosses the line of no effect becomes an insignificant study. So studies A, B, and C are statistically insignificant (option B).

The dotted vertical line in the center represents the aggregate risk ratio and is not the line of no effect. Studies D and E do not cross the line of no effect (option D).

Related Pearl: Forest Plot

  • A forest plot is used to present the results of a meta-analysis.
  • It is also called blobbogram.

Interpretation of forest plots: 

  • The rectangles represent the single studies
  • The size of the rectangle is proportional to the sample size
  • The horizontal line on either side - confidence interval, the longer the lines, the wider the confidential interval, the less reliable the study results
  • The vertical solid line - the “line of no effect", which represents the odds ratio or relative risk. If it is the odds ratio, then the vertical line would be at 1. No difference between the intervention and the placebo (i.e., a risk ratio of 1). 
  • The location of the result - whether it favours the intervention (the statin drug) or not
  • A diamond shows the overall pooled result where all the individual studies are combined together and averaged
  • Lateral corners of the diamond represent the confidence interval, if these corners do not cross 'the line of no effect', then there is an overall statistically significant effect. If the diamond touches the vertical line, the overall result is not statistically significant.
  • The vertical dashed line represents the overall pooled estimate which represents the meta-analysed measure of effect.

Let's understand with an example - 

  • For study A- it has a wide horizontal line that crosses the line of null effect with a black box that is to the right of the vertical line. This most likely demonstrates a small scale study with few participants where the point estimate result favours the control used in the study. But because the study contains the null value in its 95% confidence interval, it is likely to have a p-value >0.05 and not be statistically significant.
  • For study B- it has quite a narrow line that does not cross the line of null effect with a black box that is to the left of the vertical line and is bigger than study A. This most likely demonstrates a larger study with more participants compared to study A, where the result favours the intervention used. Because the 95% confidence interval does not contain the null value, this study is likely to have a p-value <0.05 and hence the differences observed in the study can be regarded as statistically significant.

questions.text: A chi-square test contingency table has 5 rows and 4 columns. What would be the degree of freedom in this case?
questions.solution:
The degrees of freedom in this case would be 12.

A chi-square contingency table has one variable in rows and another in columns. In such cases, the degrees of freedom (df) = (r-1) (c-1), where r is the number of rows and c is the number of columns.

As the above contingency table has 5 rows and 4 columns, the degree of freedom in this case is given as:

df = (5 – 1) (4 – 1) = 12

The degree of freedom is an expression of sample size for t tables. df is given as n-1, where n refers to the sample size.

Related Pearl: Degrees of Freedom

  • In general, degrees of freedom (df) is equal to the number of values minus the numbers of parameters estimated on the way to the obtaining a particular estimate. For example, if we want to estimate the variance between the heights of two people A and B, we would use the values of 2 heights to estimate 1 parameter. Thus, the degrees of freedom in this case would be 2 – 1 = 1.
  • For a Chi-square contingency table, the df = (r-1) (c-1), where r is the number of rows and c is the number of columns.

questions.text: A standard normal distribution is a normal distribution with:

choices.text: Mean of 1 and a standard deviation of 0
Mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1

questions.solution:
A standard normal distribution is a normal distribution with a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text: A narrow confidence interval corresponds to all of the following, except _________.
questions.solution:
A narrow confidence interval corresponds to a smaller standard error and not a larger standard error. 

Confidence interval = Mean ± 2 standard error. Therefore, a smaller standard error results in a narrower confidence interval.

Research is usually done with samples drawn from a population rather than by using the entire population. In order to get a fair idea of the population parameters, sample statistics and estimates of error in the sample are used to get a range of values. This range is the confidence interval (CI). It is estimated based on a desirable confidence level.

The confidence interval is calculated as the difference between upper and lower confidence limits. 

The width of the CI is an indication of the utility of our population parameter estimation. Factors affecting the width of the confidence interval include:

  • Desired confidence level: the width of the CI is directly proportional to the confidence level
  • Variability in the sample: the width of the CI is directly proportional to the variability in the data 
  • Sample size: the width of the CI is inversely related to the sample size

Therefore, increases in variability and confidence levels and decreases in sample size lead to wider confidence intervals. 

Standard error = SD/√ n, where SD is the standard deviation and n is the sample size. The standard error will reduce when the sample size is increased. Thus, the confidence interval will decrease in proportion to the square root of the sample size. 

Precision is the degree to which a particular value (such as an estimate of a population mean) is immune from random variation. A narrow confidence interval indicates more precision, while a wider confidence interval indicates less precision.

Related Pearl: Confidence Limits and Interval

Confidence limits are the upper and lower limits of standard errors within which a parameter value is expected to lie.

Generally, 95% confidence limits are used and they are approximately equal to the sample mean plus or minus two standard errors, i.e., 95% confidence limits = Sample mean (x̄) ± 2 standard errors.

The general formula is confidence limits = x̄ ± zσ x̄. 

  • Where z is 3 for 99.7% Cl
  • z is 2 for 95% Cl
  • z is 1 for 68% Cl

The difference between upper and lower confidence limits is called the confidence interval. Since the standard error will decrease in proportion to the square root of the sample size, the width of the confidence interval will also decrease in proportion to the square root of the sample size.

Related Pearl: The Standard Error and Related Aspects

  1. Sampling Errors: They refer to natural, expected, random variations in the data. They are not errors per se. Hence, the mean of the sample always differs from the mean of the total population. For example, consider a population with a mean weight of 75. If we take a sample of 500 people from this population, the mean weight of this sample will not be exactly 75.
  2. Random Sampling Distribution of Means (or Sampling Distribution):
    • This refers to the distribution formed when all possible sample means from a population are plotted in a frequency distribution.
    • Sampling distributions provide information into how different the samples are from each other and from the population mean.
    For example, the hemoglobin levels of 100 randomly selected women in a city are measured and their sample mean is calculated. This is done every day for a year with the same sample size but different women each time. If all the sample means of hemoglobin levels of all women are plotted on frequency distribution, the resulting distribution would be called the sampling distribution. It would resemble a normal distribution.
  3. Central Limit Theorem: According to this theorem, as the sample size increases:
    • The sampling distribution tends towards a normal distribution curve (bell curve)
      1. Regardless of the population's actual distribution shape
      2. Assuming all samples are identical in size
    • The sample mean and standard deviations become closer to the population mean and standard deviations 
  4. Standard Error of Mean (SE or σ x̄ ):
    • The standard error is a measure of the extent to which the sample means deviate from the true population mean. It is nothing but the standard deviation of the sampling distribution.
      1. Sample means closer to the population mean lead to a lower SE and a narrower and thinner distribution curve 
      2. More variation in sample means leads to a higher SE and a broader curve 
    SE = Standard deviation / √Sample size

          σ x̄ = σ/√n

Hence, SE is inversely related to √sample size.

questions.text: In a statistical analysis, the following scatter plot is obtained. What is the inference about the correlation coefficient according to the plot?

choices.text: There is a linear negative correlation with correlation coefficient equal to -1
There is a linear positive correlation with correlation coefficient equal to +1
There is a linear positive correlation with correlation coefficient equal to zero
There is a linear negative correlation with correlation coefficient equal to zero

questions.solution:
The above scatter plot shows a linear positive correlation, with the correlation coefficient +1 [rise in the value of (X) proportionately raises the value of (Y)]

The correlation coefficient can be determined using the appearance of the scatter plot. In the given scatter plot, all the plotted points can fit a straight line perfectly. Hence the correlation coefficient is +1. Conversely, if it is not possible to draw a straight line that would fit the plotted points, the correlation coefficient would be zero.

Related Pearl: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient. It is represented by r.

  • Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).
  • Value (size) of the coefficient: Indicates the strength of relationship
  • Sign of the coefficient: Indicates direction of relationship

Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak.

The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below

Examples:

Types of correlation coefficients

  1. Pearson coefficient
  2. Spearman coefficient

Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable.

questions.text: Which of the following sampling technique is depicted in the image below:
questions.solution:
The above image depicts the technique of stratified random sampling. A stratified random sample is obtained by:

  1. Separating the population into non-overlapping groups called strata
  2. Then obtaining a proportional simple random sample from each group
  3. The individuals within each group should be similar in some way

This method of sampling avoids bias for being discriminatory for a particular group.

Option A) Simple random sampling: Sample drawn in such a way that every element in the population has an equal probability of being included.

Option C) Snowball sampling: This method is used when the population cannot be located in a specific place, and therefore, it is difficult to access this population.

Option D) Cluster sampling: This method is used when creating a sampling frame is nearly impossible due to the large size of the population. In this approach, the population is divided into clusters based on geographic location. A list of all clusters is created, and investigators randomly select a number of clusters to be included. Next, they list all individuals within these selected clusters and conduct another round of random selection to obtain a final random sample, similar to simple random sampling. This method is called multistage sampling because the selection process occurs in two stages: first, the selection of eligible clusters, and second, the selection of individuals from within those clusters.

questions.text: Which of the following statistical tests will you use to compare the C-reactive protein (CRP) levels in 3 patient groups treated with different drugs: remdesivir (Group 1), hydroxychloroquine (Group 2), and systemic steroids (Group 3)?
questions.solution:
An analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to compare the means among three or more groups. 

The t-test and analysis of variance (ANOVA) are statistical methods used in the testing of hypotheses for the comparison between the means of groups.

The independent t test, also called the unpaired t-test, is a statistical test that determines whether there is a statistically significant difference between the means in two unrelated (independent) groups. A comparison between BMI in males and in females of a population is an example of a case where an unpaired t-test is used.

The paired t-test compares paired data, or pre-intervention and post-intervention data, of the same group. If a study were to compare BP in a group of patients before and after treatment, then a paired t-test would be used.

Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric (non-numeric) test, and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data. In the given study, if CRP levels in each group were categorized as high and low and the three groups were then compared, then the chi-square test would be used.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: Hemoglobin (Hb) levels were measured in 200 pregnant women and a mean value of 10.5 g/dL was obtained with a standard deviation of 0.5 g/dL. Assuming a normal distribution, what is the percentage of the study population with Hb <10g/dL?
questions.solution:
16% of the study population would have a Hb <10 g/dL.

Assuming a normal distribution, if the mean is 10.5 g/dL, 68% of the study population would have an Hb between 10-11 g/dL, being within 1 standard deviation. 

This means that, of the remaining population of 32% (100-68=32) falling outside 1 standard deviation, half of them, i.e., ½ of 32% = 16%, would have a Hb <10 g/dL and 16% would have a Hb >11 g/dL.

In a normal distribution, the distribution of values around the mean is as follows:

  • 68% of the distribution falls within ±1 SD of the mean
  • 95% of the distribution falls within ±2 SD of the mean
  • 99.7% of the distribution falls within ±3 SD of the mean

Other Options:

Option A: 32% of the population would represent all those falling outside 1 standard deviation of the mean value of 10.5, i.e., the group that has a Hb<10 g/dL and Hb>11 g/dL.

Option C: 68% of the population would represent all those falling within 1 standard deviation of the mean value of 10.5, i.e., the group that has a Hb>10 g/dL and Hb<11 g/dL.

Option D: 95% of the population would represent all those falling within 2 standard deviations of the mean value of 10.5, i.e., the group that has a Hb < 9.5 g/dL and Hb>10.5 g/dL.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text: Which of the following leads to an increase in the power of a statistical test?
questions.solution:
Increasing the sample size will increase the power of a study. In fact, increasing the sample size is the most practical and most important way of increasing the power of a study.

Other factors that increase the power of a study are:

  • Increasing alpha
  • Decreasing beta
  • Decreasing sampling error
  • Increasing effect size (increase in difference between sample mean and hypothesized population mean)

questions.text: Which of the following concepts in the hypothesis testing is incorrect?

choices.text: Alpha is the maximum tolerable probability of a type 1 error being made
Beta is the probability of a type II error
When the null hypothesis is true but rejected, it is a type II error
P value can be more or less than alpha

questions.solution:
When the null hypothesis is true but is yet rejected, it is a type I error.

Type II errors are when an alternative hypothesis is rejected even though it is true.

Related Pearl: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

  • A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.
  • It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.
  • If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.
  • It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

  • The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.
  • In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.
  • A null hypothesis is represented by H0.
  • If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

  • If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.
  • When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.
  • By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.
  • Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

  • The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was not obtained by chance.
  • It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.
  • From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.
  • This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.
  • It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.
  • The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.
  • Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

  • The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.
  • It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.
  • If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.
  • The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

  • The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.
  • It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.
  • By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.
  • Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.
  • A test's power will increase in the following conditions:
    • If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.
    • If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.
    • If sampling error decreases.
    • If the sample size (n) increases.

questions.text: A study on mood stabilizers shows that a new drug X works faster to stabilize mood than the standard drug Y. The results are statistically significant. The study is carried out 100 different times and shows such significant differences 95 times. Which of the following accurately characterizes the probability of not detecting a correlation between X and Y in this study?
questions.solution:
The likelihood of not detecting a correlation between X and Y is nothing but a type II error or a beta error which is 5%.

A type II error is the probability of rejecting the alternate hypothesis when it is true. It is also known as a beta error.

In this case, it is the chance of saying the experimental drug does not work better than the standard drug, while it does. This happened in 5/100 studies, hence the likelihood of a type II error (beta) is 5%.

Note: Power = 1- beta. Here, the power of the study is 95%.

Related Pearl: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

  • A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.
  • It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.
  • If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.
  • It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

  • The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.
  • In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.
  • A null hypothesis is represented by H0.
  • If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

  • If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.
  • When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.
  • By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.
  • Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

  • The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was not obtained by chance.
  • It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.
  • From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.
  • This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.
  • It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.
  • The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.
  • Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

  • The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.
  • It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.
  • If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.
  • The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

  • The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.
  • It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.
  • By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.
  • Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.
  • A test's power will increase in the following conditions:
    • If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.
    • If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.
    • If sampling error decreases.
    • If the sample size (n) increases.

questions.text: A study is conducted to assess the blood pressures of people in different cities. Sample sizes of different cities 1, 2, and 3 are 1000, 800, and 600 respectively.  Three normal distribution curves of different sample sizes of the three cities are given below in the image. The X-axis shows the standard deviation from the mean blood pressure. The order of margin of error will be ____________.
questions.solution:
Curve 1 has the least margin of error, followed by curve 2 and then curve 3. So the order is 3>2>1.

The image shows three normal distribution curves of different sample sizes, having the same mean but different standard deviation.

As the sample size is decreasing, the peak decreases and the curve becomes flatter, implying a wider confidence interval for the given mean.

The margin of error is a statistic expressing the amount of random sampling error in the results of a survey. The larger the margin of error, the less confidence.

The width of the base of the curve is directly proportional to the margin of error. 

  • Many data such as blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc., form a normal distribution
  • A standard normal distribution is a normal distribution with a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text: An epidemiologist is calculating the incubation period for measles in children aged 2 to 14 years. He was assigned a rural area with a sizeable portion of unvaccinated children and adolescents. He takes the sample size as 100. The median incubation period is 10 days, and the standard deviation he obtains is 4. What will be the standard error in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The formula for standard error is SE = standard deviation/ square root of sample size.

In this scenario, the standard error = 4/10 = 0.4.

Related Pearl: The Standard Error and Related Aspects

  1. Sampling Errors: They refer to natural, expected, random variations in the data. They are not errors per se. Hence, the mean of the sample always differs from the mean of the total population. For example, consider a population with a mean weight of 75. If we take a sample of 500 people from this population, the mean weight of this sample will not be exactly 75.
  2. Random Sampling Distribution of Means (or Sampling Distribution):
    • This refers to the distribution formed when all possible sample means from a population are plotted in a frequency distribution.
    • Sampling distributions provide information into how different the samples are from each other and from the population mean.
    For example, the hemoglobin levels of 100 randomly selected women in a city are measured and their sample mean is calculated. This is done every day for a year with the same sample size but different women each time. If all the sample means of hemoglobin levels of all women are plotted on frequency distribution, the resulting distribution would be called the sampling distribution. It would resemble a normal distribution.
  3. Central Limit Theorem: According to this theorem, as the sample size increases:
    • The sampling distribution tends towards a normal distribution curve (bell curve)
      1. Regardless of the population's actual distribution shape
      2. Assuming all samples are identical in size
    • The sample mean and standard deviations become closer to the population mean and standard deviations 
  4. Standard Error of Mean (SE or σ x̄ ):
    • The standard error is a measure of the extent to which the sample means deviate from the true population mean. It is nothing but the standard deviation of the sampling distribution.
      1. Sample means closer to the population mean lead to a lower SE and a narrower and thinner distribution curve 
      2. More variation in sample means leads to a higher SE and a broader curve 
    SE = Standard deviation / √Sample size

          σ x̄ = σ/√n

Hence, SE is inversely related to √sample size.

questions.text: An association between ordinal position on one ranking and ordinal position on another ranking can be determined by which of the following techniques?
questions.solution:
Spearman's rank-order correlation is used to determine the association between ordinal position on one ranking and ordinal position on another ranking.

It is one of the two most commonly used correlation coefficients. It is used for ordinal scale data. The other one is Pearson product-moment correlation, which is used for interval or ratio scale data.

The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric (non-numeric) test, and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.

  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed, but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increase.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is<5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

A paired t-test compares paired data, or pre-intervention and post-intervention data, of the same group.

The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means), and here, the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

Data can be quantitative (numerical values) or qualitative (types, labels).

Quantitative data can be discrete variables or continuous variables.

Most biomedical data is continuous.

questions.text: Which of the following variables is measured on the nominal scale?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the A, B, O blood groups can be measured on a nominal scale.

Data will always fall into one of the following four scales:

  • Nominal
  • Ordinal
  • Interval
  • Ratio

Nominal scale data can be divided into qualitative categories or groups. Examples include male/female, black/white, or red/green. No order or ratio from the data is implied. Nominal data that falls exclusively into two groups is known as dichotomous data. A, B, O blood groups can be clearly divided into qualitative groups and hence can be measured on a nominal scale.

Ordinal scale data holds meaning when it is placed in a particular order. An example is the ranking of students in a class. But, there is no information about the interval size. This means that the difference between the marks of the first and second students may or may not be the same as the difference between the second and third. An example is the Glasgow coma scale and Child-Pugh score.

Interval scale data is similar to ordinal data because it can be placed in a meaningful order. Additionally, they have meaningful intervals between the items, usually measurable quantities. For example, the difference between 100° and 90° is the same as that between 50° and 40° on the temperature scale. But these scales do not have absolute zeroes, which makes ratios between the items meaningless. 

Ratio scale data have similar properties to interval scale data. In addition, they have an absolute zero. Most biomedical variables can be measured on a ratio scale. Examples are weight in pounds or grams, pulse rate in beats/minute, and blood pressure in millimeters of mercury. A pulse rate of 0 indicates a lack of pulse, and a rate of 120/minute is twice as fast as a rate of 60/minute. This means it is possible to calculate meaningful ratios. 

Other options:

Option B: Glasgow coma scale can be measured on the ordinal scale.

Option C: Intelligence quotient can be measured on the interval scale.

Option D: Respiratory rate can be measured with the ratio scale.
